Package org.xlattice.util.cmdline

This is a facility for rapidly setting up software to pick values off of command lines.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    ArgCursor
    Cursor over an array of command-line arguments.
    Bindery
    Facility for binding an array of command line arguments to a set of fields in an object.
    BooleanOpt
    Binds a boolean field in an object to a command line argument.
    CmdLineOpt
    Superclass for bindings between command line arguments and object fields.
    CmdLineSpec
    Specification for the binding between command line options and a set of fields in an object.
    DoubleOpt
    Binds a command line argument to a double field in an object.
    IntOpt
    Bind a command line argument to an int field in an object, optionally specifiying minimum and maximum value.
    LongOpt
    Binding between a command line option and a long field in an object, with optional minimum and maximum values.
    StringOpt
    Bind a command line option value to a String field.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    CmdLineException
    Exception thrown when there is an error in the command line.
    OptionDescriptorException
    Exception thrown when there is an error in the command line specification.

Package org.xlattice.util.cmdline Description

This is a facility for rapidly setting up software to pick values off of command lines.

To achieve this, you write out a recipe for the command line in the form of a list of option descriptors, something like:

static CmdLineOpt [] options = {
    // option  field
    new BooleanOpt ("b", "bFld", "boolean option"                 ),
    new DoubleOpt  ("d", "dFld", "double value option", 1.0, 100.0),
    new StringOpt  ("s", "sFld", "String option"                  ) };

Here bFld, dFld, and sFld are the names of fields in the associated object. The optional descriptions are for use in building help messages.

Then you create an object with matching fields that you set to the desired default values.

class Example {
    boolean bFld;                   // defaults to false
    double  dFld = 42;              // defaults to 42.0
    String  sFld = "not specified";
}

There can be any number of command line options and minimum and maximum values can be set for numeric types. The user does not have to enter options in the same order as in the command line specification.

You then set up main like so:

public static void main (String[] args) {
    Example ex = new Example();
    int next = Bindery.bind (args, options, ex);

The call to Bindery.bind will have set the fields in the object from the command line. If any arguments have not been used, next is the index of the first unused argument.
